Award.AwardTitle: Development of nanocomposite inorganic materials for photocatalytic production of solar fuels
Award.AbstractNarration: The Chemical Catalyis Program of the Chemistry Division of the National Science Foundation will support the research program of Professor Mikhail Zamkov at Bowling Green State University. Professor Zamkov and his students will combine novel synthesis strategies for the formation of composite charge-separating nanoparticles coupled with metallic catalyst particles, with ultra-fast spectroscopy of photoinduced charge transfer processes at the interfaces in these particles. This work will address the nature of charge transfer across these heterojunction interfaces, contributing to the basic understanding of electron dynamics in these nanomaterials. Such nanomaterial systems show promise for use as photocatalysts in water splitting reactions for the production of hydrogen and other solar fuels. The work of this project will serve to train students in the fundamental physics and chemistry of sustainable energy technologies, as well as to provide the foundation for the development of these possibly important catalytic materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research supported by the Chemical Catalysis Program has explored the synergy of chemical synthesis and optical spectroscopy to develop a novel class of nanomaterials deployable for an efficient production of hydrogen from water under visible illumination. The extraction of solar fuels from sunlight at costs that can potentially compete with petroleum products is one of key challenges, presently facing chemical sciences. To achieve this goal, the PI has synthesized and tested composite inorganic nanoparticles which exhibit tunable absorption, extensive charge separation, and large surface-to-volume ratios. Fabricated from inorganic building blocks, these materials promote an efficient absorption of light across most of the solar spectrum and efficiently convert the optical energy into electric potential for driving chemical reactions. The developed colloids have been extensively tested in hydrogen production and other types of catalytic reactions, resulting in compelling conversion efficiencies. The high performance level observed in these studies has stimulated a substantial amount of complementary research in the scientific community. The results of research activities performed under the Chemical Catalysis award were disseminated in multiple public presentations by the PI as well as through 14 peer-reviewed publications, which appeared primarily in high impact journals.

 

From the synthetic standpoint, this work has contributed to the development of low-cost colloidal techniques deployable for the synthesis of structurally-optimized composite nanoparticles with superior optoelectronic and photocatalytic properties. From the fundamental aspect, this project has explored the nature of charge transfer across nanostructured interfaces, which contributes to the basic understanding of electron dynamics in composite nanomaterials and promotes the development of nanoparticles with programmable characteristics.

 

The scope of research activities performed under this award was vastly relevant to the basic energy science and device engineering applications. It has contributed to the understanding of electron transfer and energy conversion processes that occur in inorganic nanomaterials thus promoting an alternative strategies and device architectures for visible photocatalytic systems. The developed intellectual property has the potential to be harnessed in diverse fields, including solar energy production, solar fuels research, environmental clean-up, and chemical industry. The educational aspects of this work focused on elucidating students through research activities and curriculum development. Over twenty undergraduate students have participated at different stages of the project and seven of them were sponsored to present at national meetings. Three of the undergraduate students received prestigious national awards for their research work. The developed photocatalysis testing module has been incorporated into a graduate/undergraduate curriculum. The synthetic protocols were developed into instructional videos and made available to the public (through free-access websites and video journals).
